section.para: The man had been covertly watching Van der Boschstraat 12 for several days waiting for a chance to catch Johan Jacob alone but the woman of the house had shown no inclination to go out. Johan Jacob could be seen in his workroom, presumably pouring over his maps upon the hour rather than venturing beyond his front door. It was, of course, only a matter of time before he answered the call of the ladies available to cater to his less cerebral needs. It was a pity that such a sojourn would likely take place during the evening which fact meant that the man had to suffer the volatile weather of the spring season with only some slight benefit of the cover of darkness at later hours. He had to suffer everything from being warmed by blinding sunshine to attacked by hail and sleet borne on a the winds of a squally. It was a challenge to his pride to maintain his reputation for inconspicuousness under such conditions, especially in the barrenness of a street of newly built villas. This particular day had begun with those wealthy enough to have the choice out for a stroll to enjoy the chirruping of the birdies and surging of sap in the flora whilst their servants headed along the street with more purpose, either real or invented. Although at pains to dress appropriately for the weather and change his general appearance frequently, regulars might begin to sense something familiar about him and slow movers have the time to take him in. A sudden, spring shower late in the afternoon drove everybody indoors - and soaked him to the skin! Fresh, dry clothes and novel ways to conceal himself had to be brought into play. Fortunately, activities above and below stairs relating to the ritual of dinner kept most folk off the street and away from the windows.

Now the weather had cleared up to reveal an almost full moon and brilliant with stars. Very nice and all that but the increased illumination made remaining invisible difficult yet again added to which the temperature was plummeting towards a late frost. His cold, wet feet were starting to go numb but stamping some life and warmth back into them risked giving himself away to any nosey busybody. His damp clothes were steaming dry but taking the heat from his body with them and a drip was forming on the end of his nose.

Ah, but look here! The front door was opening and, yes, the familiar figure of his quarry was emerging from it! The man quietly slipped onto the pavement behind Johan Jacob and followed him to a distance safely out of view from the house before he took a small, round stone from his pocket and lobbed it at Johan Jacob's shoulder. Without breaking his stride, Johan Jacob walked on then suddenly diverged from his route and stopped in the concealing shelter of a low hanging tree. The man walked past, looking and listening, before satisfying himself that they were alone and turning back to also duck under the dripping willow branches where Johan Jacob was waiting expectantly.

"Your taking ship for Sumatra, first tide, day after tomorrow. Go in uniform but take informal tropical clothing. We will sort you out some better gear when you get there. So, travel light and with concealed small arms . You'll be away months rather than weeks. Questions? "
Johan Jacob stared thoughtfully at his shoes then nodded his head to accept the brief before adding,
"Then I had better make haste and take full use of the delights at my destination."
With that, he turned on his heel and strode off into the night.

The man waited until the footsteps had died away before peering through the drooping willow branches to ensure that the coast was He quietly took himself off in the direction of the less salubrious parts of Den Haag where he would not attract attention in a smoke-filled bar which specialised in cheap jenever. The result of his efforts to reheat through the ingestion of rough spirit was that pretty much all of him not just his extremities, was pleasantly anaesthetized by the time he set out for the docks at Scheveningen. He had also contrived to spill most of his last shot jenever down his front, which was a waste! Luckily the novel form of the ironclad monitor vessel he was to rendezvous with was easily spotted amongst the wooden sailing ships and steam-sailers in port. The Heiligerlee was a common sight along the coast of Holland so attracted no longer attracted any undue interest by arriving in Schveningen.

The man merged himself with a group of sailors whose direction of travel indicated that they were headed in the way he wanted to go. They had clearly been ashore for a drink but were not inebriated since this would result on being put on a charge as soon as they returned to the ship. He joined them in the companionable activity of relieving themselves into the dock from the edge of the quay. As he turned inshore, having concluded his business, he staggered and went to make a step backwards which would have likely precipitated him into the water below. A large, calloused hand grasped him firmly under the arms and set him back on the right track.
"Steady as you go, Matey! You'll be for it when the officer on deck sees the state you're in!"
His saviour accompanied him to the foot of the gangway to ensure his safety before leaving him to make his slow and unsteady way to the deck at the top.

The Adelborst (or Sergeant) on duty was marking off the returning crew to make sure no one was missing but stuck his arm out when the man reached him thus preventing his further passage onto the deck. He had been watching the group of sailors as they drained their bilges and had seen this one experiencing heavy weather, rolling noticeably and being blown off course from time to time so requiring the services of a tug boat in the burley shape of the chief stoker. He reeked of alcohol and, when asked his name and rank, was unable to articulate more than a slurred mumble. Heaving a sigh of resignation, the Adelborst snapped his fingers towards the Master at Arms waiting nearby and instructed him to convey the miscreant to the brig to sober up and await being brought before the Commander on a charge.

Since the Heiligerlee was only in harbour for a few hours, most of her complement of 117 men had stayed on board so had not had opportunity to get into trouble, hence the man had th e brig to himself. A guard had been rustled up to keep and eye on him in case he hurt himself or choked on his won vomit, but mostly retreat to a discrete hideout where he could smoke, read the racing papers and doze noisily. His deception having achieved its objective, the man wrapped himself in the single, rough, navy blanket and lay down on the bunk, promptly falling into a sound sleep. He was woken by a different guard bringing in a tray of breakfast and suggesting that he visit the heads and clean himself up before being brought before Luitenant 1e klas W F Meijen.

Having availed himself of a free night's bed and breakfast, the man shed the status of 'on a charge' as soon as the commander dismissed the guard and closed his cabin door behind him. The two men could now talk in private. Lt Meijen passed across a sealed envelope which the man opened, read then used the available lucifer and metal ashtray to burn it. There was a pensive silence on the part of the man, broken by the Commander's enquiry;
"Where to?"

The Heiligerlee had been built with a shallow draft of just under 3m, armor plated sides, a low freeboard and armed with a few but heavy guns. She was designed to patrol the coast and rivers in case of invasion in the aftermath of the Franco-Prussian War. A study and useful vessel, she was also the butt of humour because of some rather unfortunate 'incidents', running aground between Dordrecht and Rotterdam then again in the opposite direction, next she hit a bridge on the same route. The threat of invasion had receded so she was hardly busy and was due to over winter in Rotterdam, but first was to convey her supernumerary crew member to his next covert job.

Now the difficulties for Theodorus and Cornelis started. The gang was the hub of the house so still constantly in use by men working on the upstairs rooms yet time needed to be devoted to getting it ready for the grand event in August. This meant that all of the upstairs rooms which would be needed had to be given priority now so that they, too, could be sealed off whilst the central gang , trappenhuis, or staircase, and witte overloop, or white landing, were decorated. Then, working forwards, the ground floor family rooms must be completed, not to mention laying the groundwork for a working kitchen. All of this must be made ready in time for carpets to be laid, curtains hung, furniture placed, and all the many objects put on display. The only slight relief to this immense schedule of work was the decision by the family not to use part of the house. Paulina and her husband would be returning to their own house to sleep so the upstairs suite of rooms behind the carefully installed witte bovenportaal, or white screen and door, would not be needed. Also, since Marcellus was not the host but the guest of honour, the formal grote salon and eetkamer, or dining room, intended as function rooms would not be needed either. Already these rooms had been tidied and cleaned with the workmen redeployed to other parts of the house.

The situation which had been the trigger for the heated exchange between Theodorus and Cornelis earlier in the day now had to be addressed. The area of the house into which a full compliment of existing men plus the new workers drafted in that day had to operate was drastically reduced. The men themselves had instituted a system of entering by the kitchen door and exiting through the garden room door after several collisions and hold ups had frustrated tempers and damaged goods. This had not solved all of their issues as conflicts over who was doing what and where had proliferated. Theodorus recognised that he needed to manage the situation by allocating specific jobs to men and making sure that they were making due progress, reviewing the whole effort on at least a daily basis and adjusting deployments as necessary. He needed Cornelis to contribute to the identification of what needed to be done and to apply his knowledge of the men's capabilities to their allocation. The two men needed to be sure that they didn't contradict each other in directing the work yet dividing the overseeing between them to keep things in manageable proportions.

Theodorus was to take charge of the plasterwork and Cornelis the woodwork, that much was easy to decide as it played to their specialities. How to apportion the painters needed some consideration as both plasterwork and woodwork needed painting. However, there was painting and then there was painting. Applying base coats of paint required minimal skill. Colouring large areas of plain plaster on walls and ceilings required enough skill to give an even finish. Similarly smaller but plain sections of woodwork, such as doors and skirtings. Then there was carved wood and simple plaster mouldings needing care but not the skilled brushwork of intricate carvings and mouldings, especially where a steady hand and narrow brush were involved. Then there were the special techniques involved in imitating marble and different types of wood. These later stages of decoration needed carefully arranged drying times to cope with the application of different colours and finishes.

The planned use of rooms in the house during Marcellus's day of celebration was to begin with entry by the front door, passing through to the vestibule and from thence into the kleine salon where refreshments were to be served. When the Burgermeester was called to join the celebrations in his honour, he and his guests would pass through to the gang (making use, if necessary, of the modern toilet with its wooden casing wide enough to accommodate the ladies' vast skirts, marble walls and flushing bowl), ascend the trappenhuis to the witte overloop and from there into a small room that led out onto the balcony above the front door where Marcellus would stand to view the entertainments. Since the balcony itself was quite small, guests could also view proceedings from one of the large windows from a narrow gallery above the staircase. These areas of the house had to be ready in time and completed to the highest possible standard to honour Marcellus. Also, the burgermeester needed to be sure that his guests were sufficiently impressed in order to vindicate his decision to build a new house.

Out of the eyes of all but his closest family (and servants), the Burgermeeseter's private chambers led off the witte overloop through a frosted glazed door and screen, white on one side to match the entrance to Paulina's quarters opposite and brown on the other to follow the theme of Marcellus's rooms. Beyond this entrance lay a central hall the eponymous bruine overloop or brown hall. A door on the left leading towards the front of the house gave into Marcellus's bedroom and thence to his dressing room and the innovation of a bathroom. It was expected that Marcellus would spend at his first night here following his anniversary celebrations so these rooms also needed to be prepared to at least as high a standard as the areas of the house on general view. This was the most challenging part of the whole construction project, especially the bedroom where the Burgermeester had given his taste for the trappings of position and wealth full rein.

The imposing grey and red marble fireplace ensemble filled the space between floor and ceiling in the centre of the west wall. The ornate carvings of the sections above and below the mirror had survived relocation without cracks, chips or any more significant damage thanks to careful packing in fine cotton gauze, straw and sacking before being crated up. The less ornate sections had also been wrapped and crated in straw, but this had been a simpler task. The huge mirror with its curved shaping top and bottom had been similarly stored with great care, as had its delicate wooden mounting frame. Everyone concerned with installing the whole ensemble in its new location breathed a sigh of relief when this had been safely accomplished. Only one alteration had been required being the relatively straightforward job of taking a bit off the bottom of the pillars either side of the fire grate which had originally been taller and, some said, in better balance with the mirror section.

Cornelis Straver and his team of craftsmen could then finish installing the Mahogany wood paneling which Marcellus had commissioned. He had specified that all of the woodwork be in the 18th Century French Regency style, which had sent Cornelis scurrying off to France on a visit to the grand palaces of Verssailes and Fontainbleau to see for himself the sort of thing Marcellus had in mind. The delicate, curving shapes of the panels which edged the ceiling, rather than plaster cornicing, were something different from the rest of the house and presented Cornelis with an enjoyable challenge to his skill. Theodorus might have felt he got off lightly as the plasterwork in this chamber consisted of one, large and very smooth area on the ceiling and another small oval above the entry door. However, he then had the nightmare of finding a artist who was more than competent to execute the swirling skies and cavorting angels which continued the French theme on these flat areas of plaster. It was something of a relief that the plain wall areas inside their rectilinear wooden frames were more simply decorated. in plain, dark green with delicate, gold leaf tracery borders.

Not only had Marcellus given himself a stylish bedroom but also the luxury of a separate dressing room, the only one in the house. As was the bathroom leading from it, equipped with running hot and cold water and a zinc bath tub. The hot water had to be pumped up from the well under the kitchen terrace and heated in a geyser. The cold water was collected rainwater from the roof then held in a reservoir tank in the attic above. This arrangement gave sufficient pressure to work the taps and toilet flushes. He had done himself proud but not extended his largess to the quarters for his daughter and her husband, which were more conventional although they could not be describes as spartan by any stretch of the imagination. Nor were the meeting room and guest bedroom beyond which were accessed through the door off the bruine overloop towards the back of the house as luxurious as Marcellus's chambers, although he had insisted that the family crests were prominent in the decor.

On a more domestic note, the downstairs huiskamer where Marcellus and his family could sit and could take their meals once he was in residence, needed to be available for use. Since the celebration was to be in late August and some further weeks of fine weather were anticipated, the adjacent tuinkamer, or garden room, leading through huge, glass doors to a covered terrace and riverside garden beyond should be tidied for use by restless guests. By the end of their deliberations, Thoedorus and Cornelis had produced a daunting schedule of work and were rather down hearted to realise that they would not be able to rest on their laurels after the celebrations as much would still remain to be done and with the added complication of the master being in residence from time to time when not away on business or political involvement. Noise and mess would need to be kept to a minimum when Marcellus was home.
